main_text:
Semantics
3. Semantics

Semantics for free logics differ in how they assign truth-values to
atomic formulas that are empty-termed—i.e., contain at
least one empty singular term. There are three general approaches:

Negative semantics require all empty-termed atomic
formulas to be false,
Positive semantics allow some empty-termed atomic
formulas not of the form E!t to be true, and
Neutral (or nonvalent) semantics require all
empty-termed atomic formulas not of the form E!t to be
truth-valueless.
